company.name: HireRight Solutions, Inc.
company.business_description: HireRight Solutions (formerly USIS Commercial Services, Inc.) is a consumer reporting agency that provides background screening reports to employers throughout the United States containing public record information, including criminal histories of individuals, to assist employers in making employment-related decisions.

case_info.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a); Section 13(b) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 53(b); Section 16(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 56(a); Section 621(a) of the Fair Credit Reporting Act, 15 U.S.C. § 1681s(a)

complaint.factual_background: HireRight Solutions, a consumer reporting agency providing background screening reports to employers, systematically violated the Fair Credit Reporting Act by failing to ensure accuracy of consumer reports, denying consumers access to their files, refusing to conduct proper reinvestigations of disputes, and failing to notify consumers when reporting public record information. These failures led to inaccurate reports being provided to employers, resulting in prospective employees being denied employment or employment-related benefits based on erroneous information.

counts.title: Failure to Ensure Maximum Possible Accuracy
counts.representation: Defendant was required to follow reasonable procedures to assure maximum possible accuracy of consumer report information
counts.fact: Defendant failed to follow reasonable procedures to assure that information reflected current public record status (such as expungements), failed to prevent multiple entries for the same criminal offense, and failed to prevent inclusion of obviously erroneous information such as records of other consumers with different names, dates of birth, or identifiers
counts.conclusion: By and through the acts and practices described in Paragraph 13, Defendant has violated section 607(b) of the FCRA, 15 U.S.C. § 1681e(b)

counts.title: Failure to Disclose Consumer File Information
counts.representation: Defendant was required to disclose to consumers, upon request, all information maintained in their consumer report files
counts.fact: Defendant either failed to provide consumers with information in their files or failed to do so upon request, with systems resulting in delays or non-fulfillment of requests due to inadequate staffing or technical problems
counts.conclusion: By and through the acts and practices described in Paragraph 16, Defendant has violated section 609(a)(1) of the FCRA, 15 U.S.C. § 1681g(a)(1)

counts.title: Failure to Conduct Proper Reinvestigations
counts.representation: Defendant was required to conduct reinvestigations of disputed items in a consumer's file upon receipt of a notice of dispute
counts.fact: Defendant did not conduct reinvestigations upon receipt of dispute notices, instead requiring consumers to first obtain a copy of their report before initiating reinvestigation, which delayed the process and made it more difficult for consumers
counts.conclusion: By and through the acts and practices described in Paragraph 17, Defendant has violated section 611(a)(1)(A) of the FCRA, 15 U.S.C. § 1681i(a)(1)(A)

counts.title: Failure to Provide Written Notice of Reinvestigation Results
counts.representation: Defendant was required to provide written notice to consumers of the results of reinvestigations
counts.fact: Defendant closed dispute reinvestigations without providing written notice of the results to affected consumers
counts.conclusion: By and through the acts and practices described in Paragraph 18, Defendant has violated section 611(a)(6) of the FCRA, 15 U.S.C. § 1681i(a)(6)

counts.title: Failure to Comply with Public Record Information Requirements
counts.representation: Defendant was required to either notify consumers at the time public record information was reported or maintain strict procedures to ensure the information was complete and up to date
counts.fact: Defendant neither notified consumers at the time information was reported (their multi-step notification process was not initiated until the day the report was transmitted and typically took more than one day to complete) nor maintained strict procedures to ensure information was complete and up to date
counts.conclusion: By and through the acts and practices described in Paragraph 20, Defendant has violated section 613(a)(1)-(2) of the FCRA, 15 U.S.C. § 1681k(a)(1)-(2)

definitions.Defendant: HireRight Solutions and its successors and assigns.
definitions.FCRA definitions: The definitions set forth in the FCRA, 15 U.S.C. § 1681a, et seq., shall apply.

provisions.title: Civil Penalty
provisions.summary: Judgment of $2.6 million is entered against Defendant as a civil penalty for FCRA violations, payable within 7 business days by electronic fund transfer.

requirements.description: Pay civil penalty of $2.6 million to Treasurer of the United States by electronic fund transfer

provisions.title: Prohibited Business Activities
provisions.summary: Defendant is permanently restrained and enjoined from failing to maintain reasonable procedures to assure maximum possible accuracy of consumer reports and from various other FCRA violations.

provisions.title: Recordkeeping Provisions
provisions.summary: Defendant must create and retain specific records for 5 years after entry of Order, including accounting records, personnel records, customer files, complaints, training materials, and compliance documents.

requirements.description: Maintain accounting records showing revenues from all goods or services sold, all costs incurred, and resulting net profit or loss

provisions.title: Compliance Monitoring
provisions.summary: Commission and Plaintiff are authorized to monitor Defendant's compliance through document requests, depositions, interviews, discovery, and other lawful means including posing as consumers.

provisions.title: Retention of Jurisdiction
provisions.summary: Court retains jurisdiction of this matter for purposes of construction, modification, and enforcement of the Order.

provisions.title: Costs and Attorneys' Fees
provisions.summary: Each party shall bear its own costs and attorneys' fees incurred in connection with this action.
